channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Russia Shakes Up Military Leadership Again
item.description: A general named just three months ago to lead Russian forces in Ukraine has been replaced with a Kremlin insider who helped orchestrate the invasion.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times

item.title: ‘A Wild Card’: Son of Uganda’s President Jostles to Succeed His Father
item.description: General Muhoozi Kainerugaba has been positioning himself as Uganda’s next leader. But his provocative tweets have unnerved Ugandans and put his father in a bind.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: General Muhoozi Kainerugaba at his birthday party in Entebbe, Uganda, in May.

item.title: In Israel, Netanyahu’s Hard-Right Agenda Gains Steam
item.description: Benjamin Netanyahu’s government is pushing to upend the judiciary, entrench Israeli control of the West Bank and strengthen ultraconservative Jews, fueling protests and deepening Israel’s divisions.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: An election rally for Benjamin Netanyahu in Sderot, Israel, in October. Mr. Netanyahu said this week that voters had given his government “a clear and strong mandate.”

item.title: A Vital Question for Brazil’s Democracy: Where Were the Police?
item.description: Their early inaction in Sunday’s riot shows how security forces can help empower violence and deepen the threat to democracy.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: Brazilian military police officers in Brasília, the capital, during the attack on Sunday.

item.title: Kyiv Workers Find Their Way Online Even as Ukraine Faces Power Outages
item.description: Sporadic power outages have people resorting to makeshift office spaces in the Ukrainian capital. Stores have set up power hubs, and workers are getting comfortable doing their jobs in home furnishing displays.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Uliana Kychenko, a freelance marketing manager, works from a table in a co-working space set up in Epicentr, a department store in Ukraine’s capital, Kyiv.

item.title: Iran Protests: People Executed or Sentenced to Death in Crackdown
item.description: An updated look at the Iranians who have been hanged, and those on death row, as the government tries to crush a monthslong uprising.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Cora Engelbrecht
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: via Getty Images; via Amnesty; via Twitter; via Radio Zamaneh
item.media:description: In a one-month period, Majid Reza Rahnavard, Mohammad Mehdi Karami, Mohsen Shekari and Sayed Mohammad Hosseini were executed after fast-tracked trials in Iran.

item.title: Uganda’s Worst Ebola Outbreak in Two Decades Is Over, W.H.O. Declares
item.description: The virus spread to nine districts nationwide, infecting hundreds and killing dozens. Seven health workers were among those who died.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: A victim of Ebola being buried in Mubende, Uganda, in October. The country has endured several Ebola outbreaks over the years.

item.title: Online Anger Over China’s Covid Pivot Shows Widening Social Split
item.description: The Communist Party’s efforts to limit discord over its sudden “zero Covid” pivot are being challenged with increasing rancor, including from its own supporters.
item.dc:creator: Chang Che, Claire Fu and Amy Chang Chien
item.media:description: Passengers pushing their luggage through the international arrivals hall at Beijing Capital International Airport in January after China lifted its quarantine requirement for inbound travelers.

item.title: Paris Police ‘Neutralize’ Man After Stabbings at Gare du Nord
item.description: An assailant injured six people with what French authorities described as a sharpened metal hook. The motive was not immediately clear.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: French police officers secured the area after an attack at the Gare du Nord train station in Paris on Wednesday.

item.title: Death Toll in Peru Rises to 47 Amid Extraordinary Violence
item.description: “What happened yesterday was really a massacre,” said one human rights activist.
item.dc:creator: Mitra Taj, Julie Turkewitz and Genevieve Glatsky
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Juan Carlos Cisneros/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Hundreds of protesters gathering on Monday in the Andean region of Puno in support of the ousted president, Pedro Castillo.

item.title: This Is What Shanghai’s Covid Outbreak Looks Like
item.description: The Chinese city is being gripped by a massive Covid wave, leading to a surge in hospitalizations and crowded funeral homes.
item.dc:creator: Qilai Shen and David Pierson
item.media:description: Patients and their loved ones in the lobby of a Shanghai hospital on Friday.

item.title: ‘We’re True Partners,’ Biden Says, After Meeting With Leaders of U.S. Neighbors
item.description: President Biden, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada and President Andrés Manuel López Obrador of Mexico said they had discussed economic cooperation, drug trafficking, migration and climate change during their summit in Mexico City.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: From left, President Biden, President Andrés Manuel López Obrador of Mexico and Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada in Mexico City on Tuesday.

item.title: Prince Harry Skewers Palace Culture With Nicknames and a Dose of Rancor
item.description: Along with the juicy tidbits Prince Harry offers up in his new memoir, there is also a revealing look at how the royal family, and its staff, operate behind closed doors.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: A display of Prince Harry’s book in the window at Waterstones in Piccadilly, central London.

item.title: What Does It Mean to Provide ‘Security Guarantees’ to Ukraine?
item.description: A postwar Ukraine will want to ensure that Russia does not attack again. But is there anything short of full NATO membership that will satisfy Kyiv and deter Moscow?
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers heading to the front line in the Donetsk region of Ukraine last month. Without some form of security guarantee for Ukraine after the war, experts say, it is hard to imagine the country will be able to rebuild and avoid future conflicts.

item.title: With F.B.I. Search, U.S. Escalates Global Fight Over Chinese Police Outposts
item.description: Beijing says the outposts aren’t doing police work, but Chinese state media reports say they “collect intelligence” and solve crimes far outside their jurisdiction.
item.dc:creator: Megha Rajagopalan and William K. Rashbaum
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
item.media:description: F.B.I. agents searched a suspected Chinese police outpost located at this glass building on East Broadway in New York’s Chinatown.

item.title: In a First, South Korea Declares Nuclear Weapons a Policy Option
item.description: President Yoon Suk Yeol said that if North Korea’s nuclear threat grows, his country may build a nuclear arsenal of its own or ask the United States to redeploy in the South.​
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: President Yoon Suk Yeol of South Korea in Seoul on Tuesday.

item.title: Driver in Guangzhou, China, Runs Down Pedestrians, Killing at Least 5
item.description: The police in Guangzhou detained a 22-year-old man, who appeared to throw money in the air after striking the people. Thirteen people were injured.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May
item.media:description: An image from a video taken Wednesday at an intersection in Guangzhou, China, after numerous pedestrians were struck by an S.U.V.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Aides have found more files retained by President Biden dating from his vice presidency.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: President Biden has said his staff had fully cooperated with the National Archives.

item.title: Video Shows Brazil Rioters Breaching Inadequate Security
item.description: The invasion of Brazil’s halls of power began with a severe shortfall of security forces.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas, André Spigariol, Flávia Milhorance and Ana Ionova

item.title: U.S. and Japan Say They Will Strengthen Military Cooperation
item.description: Top officials from the two nations are meeting in Washington this week to discuss tensions with China, Russia and North Korea and to plan for deterrence with U.S. troops and missiles.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Airborne troops from the United States, Japan, Britain and Australia participated in joint exercises in Funabashi, Japan, on Monday.

item.title: Russia Replaces Commander for Ukraine War, as Signs of Dissension Grow
item.description: Allies of President Vladimir V. Putin contradicted each other about battlefield progress, as a war command shake-up put another Kremlin loyalist in charge.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:description: Ukrainians firing a mortar toward Russian positions near Bakhmut on Wednesday.

item.title: Iran Gives Death Sentence to Former Defense Official, a Dual U.K. Citizen
item.description: Alireza Akbari, a former deputy defense minister, was convicted of spying, in a case he described as a slap at Britain, where he had lived.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: Alireza Akbari

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: A Russian Military Shake-Up
item.description: Also, Brazil investigates the riots and Australia reacts to Cardinal George Pell’s death.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers turn away as a 152mm Howitzer is fired into the Russian controlled town of Pisky, Ukraine, on Monday.

item.title: Navalny’s Wife Pleads for Medical Treatment for Jailed Husband
item.description: Yulia Navalny said that her ailing husband, Aleksei Navalny, was being held in a small cell with a sicker person to infect him, and was not allowed to lie down throughout the day despite having a fever.
item.dc:creator: Eric Nagourney
item.media:description: Aleksei A. Navalny, the Russian opposition leader, in a video link from prison in September last year.

item.title: Rehman Rahi, 97, Eminent Kashmiri Poet Who Restored a Language, Dies
item.description: Kashmir’s unofficial poet laureate, he gave voice to the rich culture of a bitterly divided territory and helped give his mother tongue a distinct literary identity.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:credit: Sipra Das/The The India Today Group, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Rehman Rahi in 2007, after becoming the first Kashmiri to win India’s highest literary award.

item.title: Ukraine Strips a Pro-Putin Politician of His Citizenship
item.description: Viktor Medvedchuk, a Ukrainian politician who is close to the Russian president, was handed over to Moscow in September as part of a prisoner swap while awaiting trial on treason charges.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:description: Viktor Medvedchuk, center, leaving a court hearing in Kyiv, Ukraine, in 2021.

item.title: Another Big Boomer Effect
item.description: One generation’s impact on the work force.
item.dc:creator: Ben Casselman
item.media:description: Construction employers have continued to add jobs at a solid pace.

item.title: Zelensky Thanks the ‘Free World’ in a Message at the Golden Globes
item.description: “There will be no third world war,” the Ukrainian president said. “It is not a trilogy. Ukraine will stop the Russian aggression on our land.”
item.dc:creator: Julia Jacobs

item.title: They Won Guantánamo’s Supreme Court Cases. Where Are They Now?
item.description: The three former Guantánamo prisoners who defeated George W. Bush at the Supreme Court in landmark cases are ensconced in family life. We caught up with two of them. One is a home-heating serviceman in central England; the other is an Uber driver in the French Riviera.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg and Cristina Baussan
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Cristina Baussan for The New York Times

item.title: The New Soldiers in Propane’s Fight Against Climate Action: Television Stars
item.description: An industry group is spending millions of dollars to push back against efforts to move heating away from oil and gas.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:description: Matt Blashaw, an HGTV fixture, is a paid influencer for a fossil fuel industry group that has become one of the biggest opponents of government efforts to wean U.S. homes and businesses off oil and gas in favor of cleaner electricity.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: At least 17 more civilians have died in extraordinary violence in Peru.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Juan Carlos Cisneros/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Hundreds of protesters gathering on Monday in the Andean region of Puno in support of the ousted president, Pedro Castillo.

item.title: Biden Defends His Immigration Policy as Summit in Mexico Wraps Up
item.description: Even as President Biden and the leaders of Canada and Mexico sought to emphasize their shared commitments, the tricky issue of immigration dominated much of the discussion.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and Anushka Patil
item.media:description: President Biden, President Andrés Manuel López Obrador of Mexico and Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada in Mexico City on Tuesday.

item.title: George Pell, Cardinal Whose Abuse Conviction Was Overturned, Dies at 81
item.description: An adviser to Pope Francis and a prominent figure in Australia, Cardinal Pell went to prison on charges of abusing two boys in the 1990s, but a higher court later acquitted him.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost and Damien Cave
item.media:description: Cardinal George Pell in Sydney in 2008. He later became one of the highest-ranking figures at the Vatican.

item.title: Wagner Group Claims It Has Taken Soledar, an Eastern Ukrainian Town
item.description: With a harsh winter putting sweeping offensives on hold, the war has shifted back to bloody battles of attrition like the one for the small city of Bakhmut and the smaller town of Soledar.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia, Ivan Nechepurenko and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers firing a 152-mm howitzer into the Russian-held town of Pisky, in the Donetsk region, on Monday.

item.title: After Rocky Start, Biden Builds Rapport with Mexico President López Obrador
item.description: Warm gestures by the American president have helped cement a critical relationship with a Mexican leader whose cooperation on migration, climate change and the drug trade is crucial.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff and Michael D. Shear
item.media:description: President Biden with President Andrés Manuel López Obrador at the National Palace in Mexico City on Monday.

item.title: Brazilian Authorities Arrested the Rioters. Now They Are Arresting Security Officials.
item.description: With more than 700 people arrested after supporters of Jair Bolsonaro ransacked Brazil’s seats of government, the authorities began to search for those who funded and aided the rioters.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova, André Spigariol and Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: Some supporters of Brazil’s former President Jair Bolsonaro who were arrested after Sunday’s attack in Brasília were released on Tuesday.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Shanghai’s Devastating Outbreak
item.description: Also, the eight warmest years on record and a fragile political alliance in the Philippines.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Qilai Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Patients and their loved ones in the lobby of a Shanghai hospital on Friday.

item.title: Vatican Pledges to Look Into Emanuela Orlandi Disappearance
item.description: Vatican officials said they would reopen a cold case that has gripped Italians, spawned countless theories and been the subject of a Netflix documentary series.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Pietro Orlandi, the brother of Emanuela Orlandi, a teenager who disappeared in 1983, stands with supporters, family and friends during a sit-in in 2020 in St. Peter’s Square. Their banner reads: “No state, or church can justify criminality. Truth for Emanuela Orlandi.”

item.title: Russia Reports 2022 Deficit of $47 Billion
item.description: The budget gap reached 3.3 trillion rubles, or 2.3 percent of the size of the Russian economy, according to the country’s finance minister.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: Red Square in Moscow last October. Russia’s revenues grew last year but did not keep pace with spending.

item.title: More than 200 Russian doctors petition Putin to give medical care to Navalny.
item.description: The letter, signed by doctors with their full names, was a rare example of public criticism of the Kremlin in post-invasion Russia.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Aleksei Navalny being taken from a police station outside Moscow on Jan. 18, 2021, shortly after his return to Russia from Germany, where he had recovered after being poisoned with a nerve agent.

item.title: Britain Is Considering Sending Tanks to Ukraine
item.description: The British Challenger II could become the first Western-made main battle tank to be provided to Ukraine since Russia invaded almost a year ago.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: A Challenger II tank at an arms fair in 2019 in London.

item.title: French Government Unveils Plan to Raise Retirement Age to 64
item.description: President Emmanuel Macron is focusing on cutting costs in France’s pension system, but labor unions, which fiercely oppose the measure, have promised a showdown.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: A banner bears portraits of Prime Minister Élisabeth Borne, President Emmanuel Macron and Labour Minister Olivier Dussopt. It reads “no pension for the dead people” and was part of a rally on Tuesday against the government’s pension reform plan in Rennes, in northwest France.

item.title: How Finland Is Teaching a Generation to Spot Misinformation
item.description: The Nordic country is testing new ways to teach students about propaganda. Here’s what other countries can learn from its success.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:credit: Vesa Laitinen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Olli Seppala, from left, Aatu Aho-Mantila and Arttu Hati learned about identifying misinformation in class in Hameenlinna, Finland.

item.title: Ukrainian Troops Will Travel to US to Learn to Operate Patriot Missile System
item.description: After months of debate, the Biden administration said late last month that it was sending the Patriot system to Ukraine, responding to Kyiv’s urgent request to help defend against an onslaught of Russian missile and drone attacks.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Patriot missiles in Jasionka, Poland, in March.

item.title: Robert Moller Dies at 85; Mediated Between U.N. Envoys and the City
item.description: As the U.S. liaison to some 50,000 United Nations diplomats and staff, he sought to resolve disputes on issues ranging from fugitives hiding in U.N. missions to diplomats’ unpaid parking tickets.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts

item.title: With the Return of Netanyahu in Israel, His Family Is Back, Too
item.description: Many Israelis fear that with Benjamin Netanyahu’s return to power at the head of Israel’s most right-wing government, his family members will play an outsize role in his decision making.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: Benjamin Netanyahu and his wife, Sara Netanyahu, in October at a campaign event in Migdal Haemek, Israel.

item.title: UK Bookstores React to Prince Harry’s Memoir
item.description: While some booksellers said “Spare” had generated a huge number of preorders, the reaction was mixed at stores in London, with some customers dismissive of the latest episode in a mounting royal drama.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai and Euan Ward
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Spare,” Prince Harry’s memoir, at a Waterstones bookstore in Trafalgar Square in London on Tuesday. Early-morning lines at sellers in London teemed with journalists, but regular book buyers were slower to file through the doors.

item.title: ‘Spare,’ by Prince Harry: Book Review
item.description: At once emotional and embittered, the royal memoir is mired in a paradox: drawing endless attention in an effort to renounce fame.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Jacobs
item.media:description: Prince Harry (with his brother at far left) following the coffin of their grandmother Queen Elizabeth II during a procession from Buckingham Palace in September 2022.

item.title: Jill Biden Focuses Empowerment of Women and Girls During Mexico Trip
item.description: Stressing the importance of economic opportunity, the first lady said empowered women are “the heart of a strong democracy.”
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil
item.media:description: Jill Biden, the first lady, embracing Beatriz Gutiérrez Müller, the first lady of Mexico, at an arrival ceremony with President Biden and President Andrés Manuel López Obrador of Mexico at the National Palace in Mexico City on Monday.

item.title: A Paris Cabaret Makes Way for ‘Cabaret’
item.description: The 1966 American musical has opened at a venue that for decades hosted one of the city’s most famous revue troupes.
item.dc:creator: Laura Cappelle

item.title: Prompted by Russian Aggression, EU and NATO Vow New Cooperation
item.description: A joint declaration on European security, painfully negotiated, underscores that NATO is “the foundation of collective defense.”
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: From left, Charles Michel, the president of the European Council; Jens Stoltenberg, secretary general of NATO; and Ursula von der Leyen, president of the European Commission, in Brussels on Tuesday.

item.title: Greece Opens Espionage Trial of Aid Workers Who Helped Migrants
item.description: Sara Mardini, a Syrian refugee turned activist, is among 24 people facing charges. Amnesty International has called the case “farcical.”
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: A volunteer directing a boat of refugees as they arrived on the Greek island of Lesbos in 2015.

item.title: Brazil and Jan. 6
item.description: How Brazil’s riots compare to the Jan. 6 attack.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: Planalto Palace in Brasília, Brazil, on Monday.

item.title: In the Philippines, Marcos and Duterte’s Alliance Revives Old Worries
item.description: The two scions from notorious family dynasties clinched landslide election victories in 2022, but their power balance remains fragile.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee and Camille Elemia
item.media:description: President Ferdinand “Bongbong” Marcos Jr. of the Philippines with Vice President Sara Duterte at the National Museum of Fine Arts in Manila in June.

item.title: U.S. Carbon Emissions Grew in 2022, Even As Renewables Surpassed Coal
item.description: Emissions ticked up 1.3 percent last year, even as renewables surpassed coal.
item.dc:creator: Elena Shao
item.media:description: Natural gas flaring in an oil field near Andrews, Texas, last year.

item.title: AI Is Becoming More Conversant. But Will It Get More Honest?
item.description: At a new website called Character.AI, you can chat with a reasonable facsimile of almost anyone, live or dead, real or (especially) imagined.
item.dc:creator: Cade Metz
item.media:credit: Ian C. Bates for The New York Times

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: The armies of Russia and Ukraine clash in Bakhmut.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian military analysts near Bakhmut.

item.title: In Mexico, Biden Looks for Help With Migrants and Stronger Partnership
item.description: The migration tide loomed large at the president’s summit meeting with the leaders of Mexico and Canada. All three want to steer away from the rancor of the Trump years.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and Natalie Kitroeff
item.media:description: President Biden and President Andrés Manuel López Obrador of Mexico at Felipe Angeles International Airport in Mexico City, on Sunday.

item.title: What Drove the Brazil Riots? Mass Delusion and Conspiracy Theories
item.description: Sunday’s riot laid bare a daunting threat to Brazilian democracy: Unlike past putsch attempts in Latin America, this one was driven by deeply rooted conspiracy theories.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: Government workers cleaning up the grounds of the presidential offices on Monday, a day after they were set upon by a mob.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Brazil Arrests Rioters
item.description: Also, heavy fighting rages around Bakhmut and scientists say the ozone layer is healing.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: Facade of the Planalto Palace (presidential office) vandalized by demonstrators supporting former Brazilian president Jair Bolsonaro in Brasilia, Brazil, on Monday.

item.title: Prince Harry Memoir Signals Bigger Royal Rift
item.description: The self-exiled royal has given the world a warts-and-all look at his family — with an emphasis on the warts.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: Prince Harry, Meghan, King Charles and his wife, Camilla, at the funeral of Queen Elizabeth II in September.
